description: Characterized by deficits in general mental abilities leading to impaired adaptive functioning.
Includes deficits in reasoning, problem solving, planning, abstract thinking, judgement, academic learning & learning from experience.
Disorder with onset during the developmental period.
Includes both intellectual and adaptive functioning deficits in conceptual, social, and practical domains.
Essential features include deficits in general mental abilities and impairment in everyday adaptive functioning.
Critical components of intellectual functioning include verbal comprehension, working memory, perceptual reasoning, quantitative reasoning, abstract thought, and cognitive efficacy.

related_diagnoses.Co-occurring Mental Disorders: Increased risk for suicide and accidental injury
related_diagnoses.Global Developmental Delay: Some children under age 5 years may exhibit deficits meeting criteria before full Intellectual Disability diagnosis

description: Impaired intellectual and adaptive functioning present before age 18.
Deficit in intellectual abilities measured by clinical assessment or standardized tests.

related_diagnoses.Autism Spectrum Disorder: Common comorbidity, affecting assessment of intellectual functioning.

symptoms: Persistent difficulties in acquiring and using language
Reduced vocabulary
Limited sentence structure
Impairments in discourse
Difficulties comprehending language
Word-finding problems
Poor understanding of synonyms, multiple meanings, or word play
Difficulties following instructions of increasing length
Difficulties remembering new words and sentences
Difficulties providing adequate information about key events and narrating a coherent story
description: Deficits in the acquisition and use of language due to deficits in comprehension or production

symptoms: Persistent difficulty with speech sound production
Interference with speech intelligibility
description: Difficulty with speech sound production that affects communication.
Heterogeneous in underlying mechanisms involving phonological knowledge and articulator coordination.

related_diagnoses.Language Disorder: May co-occur with speech sound disorder
related_diagnoses.Specific Learning Disorder: Poorer prognosis if associated with speech sound disorder
related_diagnoses.Developmental Coordination Disorder: Possible impairment in other areas of motor coordination

symptoms: Sound and syllable repetitions
Sound prolongations of consonants and vowels
Broken words (pauses within a word)
Audible or silent blocking (filled or unfilled pauses in speech)
Circumlocutions (word substitutions to avoid problematic words)
Words produced with an excess of physical tension
Monosyllabic whole-word repetitions
description: Essential feature of a disturbance in the normal fluency and time patterning of speech.
Interference with academic or occupational achievement or social communication.

symptoms: Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction
Deficits in social-emotional reciprocity
Deficits in nonverbal communicative behaviors
Deficits in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships
description: Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction across multiple contexts.
Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities.

related_diagnoses.Social (Pragmatic) Communication Disorde: Can be differentiated by the presence of restricted/repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities in ASD.
related_diagnoses.Intellectual Disability (Intellectual De: Co-occurs with ASD; social communication should be below that expected for general developmental level for comorbid diagnosis.

symptoms: Severe deficits in verbal and nonverbal social communication skills
Very limited initiation of social interactions
Minimal response to social overtures from others
Marked inflexibility of behavior
Extreme difficulty coping with change
Other restricted/repetitive behaviors causing significant interference with functioning
Great distress/difficulty changing focus or action
Noticeable impairments in social communication even with supports in place
Limited initiation of social interactions and reduced or abnormal responses to social overtures from others
Decreased interest in social interactions
Atypical or unsuccessful responses to social overtures of others
Difficulty initiating social interactions and clear examples of atypical or unsuccessful responses to social overtures from others
Inflexibility of behavior appearing frequently enough to be obvious to the casual observer and interfering with functioning in various contexts
Distress and/or difficulty changing focus or action
Inflexibility of behavior causing significant interference with functioning in one or more contexts
Difficulty switching between activities
Problems of organization and planning hampering independence
description: Persistent impairment in reciprocal social communication and social interaction.
Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities.

symptoms: Absent, reduced, or atypical social interest
Rejection of others
Passivity
Inappropriate approaches seeming aggressive or disruptive
Lack of shared social play and imagination
Insistence on playing by very fixed rules
Difficulty understanding appropriateness of behavior in different situations
Misunderstanding nuances of language like irony or white lies
Preference for solitary activities or interacting with people significantly younger or older
Desire to form friendships without a complete idea of their nature
One-sided or special interest-based friendships
Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities
Stereotyped or repetitive movements (hand flapping, finger flicking)
Repetitive use of objects (lining up toys)
Repetitive speech (echolalia, using 'you' instead of 'I')
Excessive adherence to routines and rigid thinking
Highly restricted, fixated interests with abnormal intensity or focus
Extreme reactions to sensory input (lights, sounds, textures)
description: Social communication deficits judged against age, gender, and cultural norms.
Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities.

related_diagnoses.Intellectual Disability: May coexist with autism spectrum disorder.
related_diagnoses.Language Impairment: Commonly associated with autism spectrum disorder.

symptoms: Marked social and communication impairments
Restricted/repetitive behaviors
Difficulties in early childhood and early school years
Developmental gains in later childhood in some areas
Behavioral deterioration during adolescence for a small proportion
Social naivety and vulnerability
Difficulties organizing practical demands without aid
Prone to anxiety and depression
Compensation strategies used to mask difficulties in public
Impairments causing current dysfunction in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning
description: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction across multiple contexts.
Defined by the presence of restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities.

related_diagnoses.Rett syndrome: May initially meet criteria for ASD due to regressive phase, but improves social communication skills afterwards.
related_diagnoses.Selective mutism: Early development is not typically disturbed. Social reciprocity is not impaired, and restricted or repetitive patterns of behavior are absent.
related_diagnoses.Language disorders and social (pragmatic: Differentiated by the presence of restricted and repetitive behavior or interests.
related_diagnoses.Intellectual disability (intellectual de: Diagnosed if no apparent discrepancy between social-communicative skills and other intellectual skills.
related_diagnoses.Stereotypic movement disorder: Not given additionally if motor stereotypies are better explained by ASD, unless they cause self-injury.
related_diagnoses.Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder: Considered when attentional difficulties or hyperactivity exceed what is typically seen in individuals with similar mental age.

symptoms: Often fails to give close attention to details
Difficulty sustaining attention in tasks or play activities
Does not seem to listen when spoken to directly
Fails to follow through on instructions
Difficulty organizing tasks and activities
Reluctance to engage in tasks requiring sustained mental effort
Loses things necessary for tasks or activities
Easily distracted by extraneous stimuli
Forgetfulness in daily activities
Fidgets with or taps hands or feet or squirms in seat
Leaves seat in situations when remaining seated is expected
Runs about or climbs in situations where it is inappropriate
Unable to play or engage in leisure activities quietly
Feels restless or driven by a motor
Talks excessively
Blurts out answers before questions are completed
Has difficulty waiting his or her turn
Interrupts or intrudes on others
description: Persistent pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity interfering with functioning.
Symptoms consistent across multiple settings.

related_diagnoses.autism spectrum disorder: may coexist, both diagnoses can be given if criteria met.

symptoms: wandering off task
lacking persistence
having difficulty sustaining focus
being disorganized
excessive motor activity
fidgeting, tapping, or talkativeness
hasty actions without forethought
interrupting others excessively
making important decisions without considering long-term consequences
low frustration tolerance
irritability
mood lability
reduced school performance
social rejection
poorer occupational performance
increased risk of traffic accidents and violations
risk of obesity
description: A persistent pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity interfering with functioning or development.
Manifests as wandering off task, lacking persistence, having difficulty focusing, being disorganized.

related_diagnoses.antisocial personality disorder: consequent increase in substance use disorders and incarceration
related_diagnoses.substance use disorders: elevated risk, especially when conduct disorder or antisocial personality disorder develops
related_diagnoses.learning disorder: associated with academic or work impairment (although not specifically diagnostic)

symptoms: Reduced school performance
Academic attainment issues
Social rejection
Poorer occupational performance
Higher probability of unemployment
Elevated interpersonal conflict
Conduct disorder development in adolescence
Antisocial personality disorder development in adulthood
Increased substance use disorders risk
Incarceration possibility
Accidents and traffic violations frequency
Obesity tendency
Laziness interpretation due to task application issues
Family discord and negative interactions
Peer rejection, neglect, or teasing
Intellectual score reduction compared to peers
Marked impairment in severe forms affecting social, familial, scholastic/occupational adjustment
Fidgetiness and restlessness
Impulsivity leading to accidental injury
Inability to sustain attention on tasks requiring effort
Forgetting instructions easily
Tantrums during transitions due to impulsivity or poor self-control
Attraction to external stimuli, new activities, or preoccupation with enjoyable activities causing inattention distinct from worry and rumination seen in anxiety disorders
Restlessness possibly seen in anxiety disorders but not associated with worry and rumination like in ADHD
Mood lability within the same day different from manic episodes lasting 4+ days indicating bipolar disorder

Excessive anger and irritability common in ADHD unlike disruptive mood dysregulation disorder featuring pervasive irritability and intolerance of frustration but lacking impulsiveness and disorganized attention unless comorbid with ADHD where both diagnoses are made separately

Difficulties distinguishing ADHD from borderline, narcissistic, and other personality disorders sharing features of disorganization, social intrusiveness, emotional dysregulation, and cognitive dysregulation though ADHD lacks fear of abandonment, self-injury, extreme ambivalence, etc.

related_diagnoses.Oppositional Defiant Disorder: Symptoms of negativity, hostility, defiance must be differentiated from aversion to school or mentally demanding tasks due to difficulty in sustaining mental effort, forgetting instructions, and impulsivity in individuals with ADHD.
related_diagnoses.Intermittent Explosive Disorder: Shares high levels of impulsive behavior but differs by exhibiting serious aggression towards others which isn't typical of ADHD nor experiencing problems with sustaining attention as seen in ADHD. Also rare in childhood.
related_diagnoses.Stereotypic Movement Disorder: Must distinguish between generalized fidgetiness & restlessness vs fixed repetitive stereotyped movements (body rocking, self biting)
related_diagnoses.Tourette's Disorder: Frequent multiple tics can be mistaken for generalized fidgetiness of ADHD. Prolonged observation required.
related_diagnoses.Specific Learning Disorder: Children may appear inattentive due to frustration/lack of interest/limited ability but inattention unrelated to academic work distinguishes it from ADHD.
related_diagnoses.Intellectual Disability (Intellectual De: Symptoms common amongst children placed inappropriately challenging academically. Not apparent during non-academic tasks. Requires excess inattention/hyperactivity relative to mental age.
related_diagnoses.Autism Spectrum Disorder: Share social dysfunction & difficult-to-manage behaviors. Social disengagement/isolation/indifference to facial/tonal communication cues differentiates ASD from social dysfunction & peer rejection seen in ADHD.
related_diagnoses.Reactive Attachment Disorder: May show social disinhibition yet lacks complete ADHD symptom cluster displaying instead lack of enduring relationships uncharacteristic of ADHD.
related_diagnoses.Anxiety Disorders: Shared symptoms include inattention caused by attraction to external stimuli/new activities/preoccupation w/enjoyable ones contrasting worry/rumination found in anxiety disorders. Restlessness possible but not linked similarly.
related_diagnoses.Depressive Disorders: Present inability concentrating but prominence occurs solely during depressive episodes differentiating from ADHD.

symptoms: inattention
hyperactivity
impulsivity
description: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by persistent patterns of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity.

related_diagnoses.Anxiety Disorders: More common than in the general population.
related_diagnoses.Major Depressive Disorder: Occurs in a minority of cases.
